questions.question: Which of the following best describes the difference between temporal summation and spatial summation in neurons? simultaneous signals at different synapses. from the same synapse.

options.A: There is no difference between Temporal summation and Spatial summation.
options.B: Temporal summation requires signals to occur close in time, spatial summation requires
options.C: Temporal summation is not limited by the refractory period, spatial summation is.
options.D: Temporal summation combines signals from different synapses, spatial summation combines signals

questions.explanation: requires simultaneous signals at different synapses. Correct Answer: B) Temporal summation requires signals to occur close in time, spatial summation requires simultaneous signals at different synapses. Explanation: Temporal summation occurs when multiple excitatory signals at the same synapse happen close in time to reach the threshold and trigger an action potential. Spatial summation involves excitatory signals arriving simultaneously at different synapses, summating to reach the threshold. Feature Temporal Summation Spatial Summation Definition (Option B) Multiple subthreshold excitatory signals at the same synapse occurring close in time. Excitatory signals arriving at different synapses simultaneously or within a short timeframe. Threshold for Excitation (Option D) Summation of signals to reach the threshold potential for triggering an action potential. Combined effect of excitatory signals at multiple synapses to reach the threshold. Signal Source (Option A) Same synapse Different synapses Current Flow Local depolarizing current spreads from the same synapse. Local depolarizing currents from different synapses overlap. Role in Action Potentials Can trigger an action potential if signals are close enough in time to summate and reach threshold. Can trigger an action potential if multiple signals from different locations summate to reach threshold. Impact of Refractory Period (Option C) Limited by the refractory period; if signals are too far apart, they won't summate. Not directly limited by the refractory period; depends on spatial proximity of signals. Examples Neurons receiving frequent, rapid signals at a single synapse. Neurons receiving simultaneous input from multiple presynaptic neurons. The longer the time constant, the greater is the chance for two potentials to summate to induce an action potential (Temporal summation) Longer the length constant, greater the chance of Spatial summation.

questions.question: Feedback control in voltage-gated ion channels in the membrane of neuron during action potential has been shown here. The phenomenon shown at point A is:
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Negative feedback Explanation : K+ channels exert Negative feedback. K I channels provide negative feedback during an action potential by promoting repolarization. Their delayed opening after depolarization allows K I ions to exit the cell, reducing the positive membrane potential and stabilizing the neuron's electrical activity. This feedback mechanism is essential for the proper functioning of neurons and for the propagation of action potentials. Positive Feedback (Option A) : Increases the activity or response, leading to a greater output. For example, during the rapid depolarization phase of an action potential, when sodium channels open and more sodium enters, it leads to further depolarization. Feedforward (Option C) : Anticipates changes and adjusts the response accordingly, but this is not the main focus in the context of ion channel behavior. Voltage-Dependent Opening (Option D) : Refers to the way ion channels open in response to changes in membrane potential, but does not describe the feedback mechanism.

questions.question: Neurologists decide to assess the excitability of different tissues by plotting the strength-duration relationship parameters on a graph. Which of the following tissues show the highest excitability?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Neuron Explanation: Neuron exhibits the highest chronaxie value. Strength-Duration Relationship Parameters The strength-duration curve graphically depicts the relationship between the intensity of an electrical stimulus applied at a muscle's motor point and the duration required to produce a minimal muscle contraction. Rheobase: Minimum electrical current (or voltage) needed to induce an action potential when applied indefinitely. Typical Values: 2 to 18 mA (or 5 to 35 volts) for healthy muscle tissue. Clinical Insight: Higher values in denervated muscles indicate reduced excitability. Chronaxie: Minimum time required for a current that is double the rheobase intensity to stimulate the muscle. Normal Value: Generally below 1 ms. Clinical Insight: Longer chronaxie indicates lower excitability. Utilization Time: Duration needed for a stimulus of rheobasic strength to excite the nerve and produce muscle contraction. Clinical Insight: Crucial for understanding nerve activation dynamics and stimulus efficiency. Clinical Significance: Assessment: Parameters assess nerve function and excitability. The order of excitability among different tissues is generally: Neurons > skeletal muscles > myocardium > smooth muscles. Additionally, A fibers are the most excitable, followed by B

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman presents to the neurology clinic with complaints of tingling and numbness in her hands and feet. On examination, the neurologist decides to conduct nerve conduction studies to assess the function of her peripheral nerves. The results show a compound action potential (CAP) with multiple peaks and a biphasic waveform. What does the presence of multiple peaks indicate?

options.A: Summation of action potentials from a single nerve fiber
options.B: Different conduction velocities of various nerve fibers

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Different conduction velocities of various nerve fibers. Explanation: The multiple peaks in a compound action potential (CAP) indicate the summation of action potentials from different types of nerve fibers (e.g., A α , A β , B, and C fibers), each with distinct conduction velocities. The different peaks reflect the sequential activation of these fibers. Action Potential - Monophasic/ Biphasic/ Compound Monophasic Action Potential: Single directional deflection, recorded from a single fiber or small group. Recording: One electrode inside the cell, the other outside. Characteristics: Single Peak: Indicates action potential of a single fiber or small group. Amplitude: Does not significantly increase with stimulation strength Follows All-or-nothing Principle. It states that once an action potential is initiated in a nerve fiber, it will travel the entire length of the fiber if the conditions are suitable, or it will not travel at all if the conditions are not right. Biphasic Action Potential: Two-phase action potential with positive and negative deflections. Recording: Two electrodes of opposite polarity detect the wave of depolarization. Characteristics: Waveform: Upward deflection followed by a downward deflection. Relation to CAP: Component of CAP, reflecting the activity of multiple fibers. Compound Action Potential (CAP): Summation of action potentials from different nerve fibers (A α , A β , B, C) in a mixed nerve. Recording: Electrodes placed on the surface of the mixed nerve. Characteristics: Multiple Peaks: Correspond to different conduction velocities; A α fibers first. Amplitude: Increases with stronger stimulation. Waveform: Biphasic , showing positive and negative deflections. Does not follow the All-or-nothing Principle.

questions.question: A 35-year-old man undergoes a minor surgical procedure on his hand under local anesthesia. Which of the following sensory modalities would be the FIRST to be lost?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Dull, aching pain. Explanation: Pain transmitted by A-d fibers that is most susceptible to blockade by local anesthetics like lidocaine. Spike potential is defined as a rapid, transient change in membrane potential, signifying an action potential. Spike duration is the length of time this spike potential lasts. Fiber Type Function Spike Duration (ms) Susceptibility to Local Anesthesia A α Proprioception, somatic motor (Option A and C) 0.4–0.5 ++ A β Discriminative Touch, pressure (Option B) ++ A γ Motor to muscle spindles ++++ A δ Pain (fast), temperature (cold) +++ B Preganglionic autonomic 1.2 ++ C Pain (slow), temperature (warm), Postganglionic sympathetic. 2 + Susceptibility to Local Anesthesia Pressure Hypoxia A γ and A δ >> A α and A β >> B >> C A α > B > C B > A > C Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 91-93.

questions.question: Match the following nerve fibre type with its respective property. Fibre type Property 1. A α β δ
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 1-d, 2-b, 3-c, 4-a Explanation: Classification of nerve fibres - Erlanger and Gasser and Lloyd-Hunt Fiber Type Erlanger-Gasser Classification Lloyd-Hunt Classification Myelination Function Conduction Velocity (m/s) Diameter (µm) Sensitivity to Blockade A α A α Ia, Ib Myelinated Proprioception, somatic motor 70-120 12-20 Pressure - Most susceptible A β A β II Touch, pressure 30-70 5-12 Pressure - Intermediate. A γ A γ Motor to muscle spindles 15-30 3-6 A δ A δ III Pain (fast), temperature (cold) 12-30 2-5 B B Preganglionic autonomic 3-15 <3 Hypoxia - Most susceptible C (Dorsal Root) C IV Unmyelinated Pain (slow), temperature (warm) 0.5-2 0.4-1.2 Local anesthetics - Most susceptible C (Sympathetic) C Postganglionic sympathetic 0.7-2.3 0.3-1.3 Reference: Classification of peripheral nerve fibres. An historical perspective - PubMed (nih.gov) Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Pages 91-92.

questions.question: Which of the following would decrease the conduction velocity of an action potential along an axon?

options.A: Increasing the diameter of the axon.
options.B: Decreasing the capacitance of the membrane.
options.D: Increasing the myelination of the axon.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Increasing the axoplasmic resistance. Explanation: Increasing this resistance would hinder the spread of Na+ ions, making it more difficult to reach the threshold for action potential initiation at adjacent nodes of Ranvier. Conduction velocity of the Action potential. Factors Influencing Myelination : Increases conduction velocity, enabling saltatory conduction. (Option D) Axon Diameter : Larger diameter axons exhibit faster conduction velocities. (Option A) Temperature : Higher temperatures increase ion channel opening and closing speeds affecting conduction velocity. Classification of Nerve Fibers Larger, myelinated fibers (like A α fibers) - Faster conduction velocity. Smaller, unmyelinated fibers (like C fibers) - Slower conduction velocity. Clinical Significance A decrease in chronaxie after nerve repair suggests increased excitability and potential regeneration. Stimulus Strength A stronger stimulus doesn't increase the speed of an action potential in a single nerve fiber, it might activate a greater number of fibers. A lower capacitance means that the membrane can depolarize more rapidly, leading to faster conduction. Myelination is a key factor in reducing membrane capacitance. (Option B) Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 91-92.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the conduction of action potentials is TRUE? axon.

options.A: Speed of action potential conduction is inversely proportional to the degree of myelination of the
options.B: Saltatory conduction occurs in both myelinated and unmyelinated axons.
options.C: The action potential jumps from one node of Ranvier to the next in myelinated axons.
options.D: The myelin sheath increases the flow of ions across the axonal membrane.

questions.explanation: axons. Correct Answer: C) The action potential jumps from one node of Ranvier to the next in myelinated axons. Explanation: The myelin sheath prevents ion flow across the membrane, forcing the action potential to "jump" from one node of Ranvier to the next. Conduction of action potential Feature Unmyelinated Myelinated Conduction Speed Slower (0.25 m/s) Faster (up to 100 m/s) Mechanism Action potential flows continuously along the axon membrane. (Option B) Action potential "jumps" between nodes of Ranvier-saltatory conduction. Myelin Sheath Absent Present, decreases flow of ions, preventing ion leakage across the membrane. (Option D) Nodes of Ranvier Absent Present, rapid action potential regeneration. Energy Efficiency Less energy efficient. More energy efficient. Fiber Diameter Smaller Larger Factors that increase action potential conduction velocity include increased myelination and increased axon diameter. (Option A) Reference: Guyton & Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 74-75. Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 91.

questions.question: What impact does hyperkalemia have on a neuron's resting membrane potential (RMP)?

options.A: It causes depolarization, making the neuron more excitable.
options.B: It causes hyperpolarization, making the neuron less excitable.
options.C: It has no effect on the RMP.
options.D: It increases the activity of the Na+/K+ -ATPase pump.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) It causes depolarization, making the neuron more excitable. Explanation: The increased extracellular potassium concentration decreases the concentration gradient for potassium to leave the cell, leading to depolarization. Condition Hyperkalemia Hypokalemia RMP Depolarized (Decreased RMP) (Option C) Hyperpolarized (Increased RMP) (Option B) Explanation Increased extracellular potassium reduces the gradient for potassium to exit the cell, causing depolarization. The resting membrane potential becomes less negative than the typical -70 mV. In hypokalemia, cells lose more potassium ions due to leaky channels. The loss of positive charge increases the negative charge within the cell, causing hyperpolarization. Effect on Neuron Excitability Increased excitability can lead to spontaneous firing and even cell death. Persistent depolarization inactivates voltage-gated sodium channels, preventing action potential generation. Decreased excitability occurs as the membrane potential is further from the threshold for action potential. Hypokalemia also inhibits the Na-K-ATPase pump. Hypocalcemia: When blood calcium is normal or high, calcium remains bound to the extracellular mouth of voltage-gated Na I channels, stabilizing them. Low blood Ca 2+ (hypocalcemia) causes calcium to detach from the channel, leading to easier sodium entry. This detachment increases Na I channel sensitivity, enhancing excitability and action potential generation. Calcium and magnesium act as membrane stabilizers. Hyperkalemia can eventually lead to increased activity of the Na+/K+-ATPase pump as a compensatory mechanism, this is not a direct or immediate effect on the RMP. (Option D)

questions.question: During an action potential, the voltage-gated sodium channel transitions through different states. Which of the following sequences accurately reflects the order of these states during a single action potential cycle starting from RMP? → Open → Inactive → Open → Closed → Open → Inactive → Inactive → Open → Closed → Open → Inactive → Closed
questions.explanation: → Open → Inactive → Closed Correct Answer: D) Closed → Open → Inactive → Closed Explanation: Stage M Gate H Gate Description Closed Closed Open This is the resting state of the voltage-gated sodium channel, where the activation gate (M gate) is closed, preventing sodium ions from entering the cell. Open Open Open When the membrane potential becomes less negative, the activation gate opens rapidly. This allows a large influx of sodium ions into the cell, leading to depolarization. Inactive Open Closed If the membrane potential remains depolarized for a prolonged period, the inactivation gate will close. The closed inactivation gate prevents sodium ions from entering.

questions.question: Which statements accurately describe the refractory period on a neuron's signaling properties?

options.A: Ensures action potentials move in one direction along an axon.
options.B: Restricts the length of an action potential, stopping overly long depolarizations.
options.C: Sets the intensity needed to start an action potential (threshold level).
options.D: Aids in the summation of local potentials, facilitating action potential generation.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Ensures action potentials move in one direction along an axon. Explanation: Action potentials are self-propagating impulses that travel down an axon with constant amplitude and velocity. During the refractory period, the portion of the membrane that has just undergone depolarization is resistant to re-excitation. This resistance ensures that the action potential moves forward along the axon rather than propagating backward to already stimulated areas. Refractory period: Refractory period is a period of reduced excitability in a neuron following an action potential. Role : Ensuring unidirectional propagation of action potentials. Modulating action potential frequency. Characteristic Absolute Refractory Period Relative Refractory Period Definition The initial phase of the refractory period. The period during which a second action potential cannot be elicited, even with a strong stimulus. Follows the absolute refractory period The period during which a stronger than-normal stimulus can elicit a second action potential. Duration Sum of the total depolarization period and the first 1/3rd of the repolarization period of the action potential. Last 2/3rd of the repolarization period of the action potential. Excitability No stimulus, no matter how strong. Stronger than normal stimuli Voltage-Gated Na+ Channels Inactive or open state. Transition from the inactive to the closed state. Significance Limits the maximum frequency of action potentials a neuron can fire. Encoding of stimulus strength by modulating the frequency of action potentials. The refractory period mainly governs the neuron's ability to generate a second action potential, not the duration of an individual action potential. (Option B) While the refractory period influences a neuron's excitability, it doesn't directly determine the threshold intensity. (Option C) The refractory period actually makes it more difficult for local potentials to summate during its time course. (Option D)

questions.question: Based on the graph showing potassium ion permeability during an action potential, at which point does the permeability of potassium ions reach its peak?
questions.explanation: are fully open, leading to the highest permeability to potassium ions. Resting Membrane Potential ( Point A on graph): At rest, the neuron's membrane potential is around -70 mV. K+ permeability is higher than Na+ permeability due to the presence of K+ leak channels. However, the overall permeability to both ions is relatively low. Depolarization Phase (Between Points A and C): Voltage-gated Na+ channels open faster than K+ channels. Rapid influx of Na+ ions, causing a rapid rise in membrane potential, causing a steep slope. Peak of Action Potential (Point C) : Na+ permeability is at its maximum. K+ channels are also opening at this stage but have not reached their peak. Early Repolarization Phase (Point D) : Early phase of repolarization. Voltage-gated K+ channels are fully open, resulting in the highest permeability. Na+ channels are rapidly inactivated during this phase. Late Repolarization and After-hyperpolarization (Points E and F): K+ permeability starts to decline as the membrane potential moves towards its resting state. Slow closure of K+ channels results in a period of

questions.question: The graph below depicts an action potential. Which of the following statements correctly describes the state of ion channels at the point marked "X" on the graph?

options.A: Na+ channels are closed; K+ channels are open.
options.B: Na+ channels are completely inactivated; K+ channels are open.
options.C: Na+ and K+ channels are open.
options.D: Na+ and K+ channels are closed.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Na+ channels are inactivated; K+ channels are open. Explanation: At the peak of the action potential (point "X"), the neuron's membrane potential is briefly positive. The voltage-gated Na+ channels are inactivated, at this same point, voltage-gated K+ channels are open, allowing K+ ions to flow out of the neuron. Phase Membrane Potential Na+ Channels K+ Channels Resting State Polarized (-70 mV) Closed Closed Depolarization (Rising Phase) Less negative, towards 0 mV. Rapidly opening, then inactivating Slowly opens. Overshoot (Peak) Briefly positive (+35 mV). Inactivated Open Repolarization (Falling Phase) Returning to negative Inactivated Open After-hyperpolarization More negative. Closed Slowly closing Return to Resting State (Option D) Returning to -70 mV Closed Closed At point "X", the peak of the action potential, voltage-gated Na+ channels are not merely closed; they are transitioning into their inactive state. (Option A) At the peak of the action potential, the voltage-gated Na+ channels are transitioning into their inactive state. (Option C)

questions.question: A 75-year-old bedridden patient presents with severe pressure ulcers over the sacral region and complaints of muscle weakness and numbness in the lower limb. On examination, there is evidence of compromised blood flow and significant tissue damage. Which layer of the peripheral nerve is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Epineurium Explanation: The fasciculi are held together by a dense layer of connective tissue called the epineurium, which surrounds the entire nerve and contains nerve fibers. In bedridden patients, loss of this protective fat layer can lead to pressure on nerve fibers, causing paralysis. Blood vessels travel through this connective tissue, so reduced blood supply can lead to ischemic neuritis and pain. Connective tissue layers of Peripheral Nerve : Endoneurium (Option B) The endoneurium is a layer of connective tissue covering each nerve fibre within its Schwann cell and basal lamina in a peripheral nerve. Contains collagen, fibroblast,schwann cells, endothelial cells and macrophages. Endoneurium holds adjoining nerve fibres together and facilitates their aggregation to form fasciculi. Perineurium (Option A) A thick layer of connective tissue covering each fascicle is called Perineurium. It comprises layers of flattened cells separated by layers of collagen fibres. Controls diffusion of substances in and out of axons. Epineurium (Option C) The fasciculi are held together by a fairly dense layer of connective tissue that surrounds the entire nerve and is called Epineurium. Contribute to the tensile strength of the nerve. Loss of this layer in bedridden patients can lead to pressure on nerve fibres and paralysis. Mesoneurium (Option D) is a connective tissue sheath that suspends the nerve trunk within the soft tissue and is continuous with the underlying epineurium

questions.question: Which of the following accurately compares local potentials and action potentials? non-decremental.

options.A: Local potentials are all-or-none; action potentials are graded and decremental.
options.B: Local potentials can summate and are decremental; action potentials are all-or-nothing and
options.C: Local potentials have constant amplitude; action potentials vary and diminish with distance.
options.D: Both local and action potentials propagate without diminishing and can summate.

questions.explanation: all-or-nothing and non-decremental. Correct Answer: B) Local potentials can summate and are decremental; action potentials are all-or-nothing and non-decremental. Explanation: Local Potentials: Graded, decremental, and can summate. Action Potentials: All-or-nothing, non-decremental, and do not summate. Feature Local Potentials Action Potentials Amplitude (Vs Option A&C) Graded; varies with stimulus strength All-or-nothing; amplitude remains constant once threshold is reached Propagation Decremental; diminishes with distance Non-decremental; maintains magnitude over long distances Summation (Option B) Can summate (spatial and temporal) Cannot summate; separated by refractory periods Function Initiate action potentials by reaching threshold at the axon hillock Transmit signals over long distances along nerve fibers Ionic Basis Involves ion movements, similar to action potentials, but often localized Depolarization and repolarization driven by voltage-gated Na I and K I channels Excitatory Postsynaptic Potentials (EPSPs): Local, Graded Potentials Depolarizing events that can trigger an action potential. Excitatory neurotransmitters bind to receptors, opening ion channels and allowing positively charged ions to enter the cell. Action potential triggered if depolarization reaches around -55 mV. Action Potential Stages: Depolarization - Opening of Na channels → fast Repolarization - Inactivation of Na channels and Exit of K → slow Hyperpolarization - Slow closure of K channels (Extra K exits) Propagation of Action Potential: Mechanism : Action potentials travel along the nerve fiber without diminishing. Depolarization at one site causes local current flow that triggers action potentials in adjacent regions. All-or-Nothing Principle : An action potential occurs only if the threshold is reached, maintaining consistent magnitude regardless of stimulus strength. Refractory Periods: Absolute Refractory Period : Na+ channels are inactivated, preventing another action potential. Relative Refractory Period : Requires a stronger stimulus to trigger another action potential due to partial repolarization. Myelination and Saltatory Conduction: Myelin Sheath insulates nerve fibers, formed by Schwann cells. Action potentials "jump" between nodes of Ranvier, speeding up transmission and saving energy. Energy Dependence: Na I -K I Pump restores ionic gradients after an action potential, consuming ATP. Factors Influencing Excitability: Calcium Ions (Ca² I ) : Low extracellular Ca² I increases excitability by lowering the activation threshold for Na I channels; high Ca² I decreases excitability. Local Anesthetics : Block voltage-gated Na I channels, reducing excitability and preventing action potentials.

questions.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes the changes in the resting membrane potential (RMP) of neuron during depolarization and hyperpolarization?

options.A: Depolarization: RMP more negative; Hyperpolarization: RMP more positive.
options.B: Depolarization: RMP more positive; Hyperpolarization: RMP more negative.
options.C: Depolarization: RMP more negative; Hyperpolarization: RMP -65 mV.
options.D: Depolarization: RMP more positive; Hyperpolarization: RMP less negative.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Depolarization: RMP more positive; Hyperpolarization: RMP more negative. I enters the neuron. Hyperpolarization: RMP becomes more negative due to excessive K I outflow or Cl I influx. Resting Membrane Potential: Typical Value: ~ -65 mV Inside of the neuron is more negatively charged than the outside. Primarily influenced by ion concentration gradients, especially potassium (K I ). Potassium Pump: Actively transports K I ions into the neuron, maintaining higher internal concentration. Creates a tendency for K I ions to diffuse out, contributing to the negative resting potential. Depolarization: Sudden shift from negative to positive membrane potential. Mechanism: Increased permeability to Na I ions allows rapid influx of Na I , neutralizing the negative potential. In large nerve fibers, Na I influx can cause the membrane potential to briefly become positive (overshoot). Excitatory Postsynaptic Potentials (EPSPs): Depolarizing events that can trigger an action potential. Excitatory neurotransmitters bind to receptors, opening ion channels and allowing positively charged ions to enter. Action potential is triggered if depolarization reaches around -45 mV. Repolarization: Return of membrane potential to resting state (-65 mV) following depolarization. Na I channels close, reducing Na I influx. K+ channels open wider, allowing K I ions to exit rapidly. Restores negative membrane potential. Hyperpolarization: Membrane potential becomes more negative than the resting potential, below -65 mV. Inhibitory Neurotransmitters: Open channels allowing negatively charged ions (e.g., Cl I ) to enter or positively charged (e.g., K I ) to exit. Prolonged Potassium Channel Opening: Allows additional K I outflow. Effect: Moves potential closer to the potassium Nernst potential, making the neuron less likely to fire immediately. Recovery: Gradual return to threshold potential for new action potential generation. Inhibitory Postsynaptic Potentials (IPSPs): Hyperpolarizing events that make it harder for the neuron to fire an action potential. Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th edition, Pg 63,64

questions.question: Match the ion with its equilibrium potential in a normal mammalian cell. Ion Equilibrium Potential (mV) 1. Sodium A. -70 2. Chloride B. +63 3. Potassium C. +132 4. Calcium D. -90
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 1-B, 2-A, 3-D, 4-C Explanation: Ion Equilibrium Potential Sodium +63 mV Chloride -70 mV Potassium -90 mV Calcium +132 mV Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 9. Guyton & Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 66-67

questions.question: A 25-year-old woman presents with symptoms of confusion and lethargy. Her blood test shows a serum sodium level of 120 mEq/L. The intracellular concentration of sodium ([Na I ] I ) is 12 mEq/L. what is the equilibrium potential for sodium (in mV)?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 61 mV Explanation: According to the question, [Na I ]outside = 120 mEq/L [Na I ]inside I = 12 mEq/L Using the Nernst equation: 'z' is the electrical charge of the ion (+1 for K+). Therefore, Eq= 61 log (120/12) = 61 log (10) = 61*(1) = 61 mV The Nernst equation calculates the electrical potential difference across a membrane (Nernst potential) that balances the diffusion of a specific ion, preventing further net movement despite a concentration gradient. The Nernst equation calculates the Nernst potential (EMF) for a single, univalent ion (an ion with a +1 or -1 charge) at normal body temperature (37°C) The Nernst potential magnitude depends on the ion concentration ratio across the membrane; larger differences result in higher potentials. Nernst equation calculates the potential for a single ion, although cell membranes are permeable to multiple ions. Applications of the Nernst Equation: Explains how ion concentration differences generate electrical potential across a selectively permeable membrane. Basis for the Goldman-Hodgkin-Katz equation, which calculates membrane potential considering multiple ions and their permeabilities. Limitations: It works best for systems with only one permeant ion. In living cells, this is rarely the case, making the Goldman equation a more accurate representation.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding the leak channels?

options.A: Facilitate the rapid transmission of action potentials along the axon.
options.B: Responsible for generation of synaptic potentials at the postsynaptic membrane
options.C: Help in maintaining resting membrane potential by allowing passive movement of ions
options.D: Play a crucial role in the repolarization phase of the action potential

questions.explanation: of ions Correct Answer: C) Help in maintaining resting membrane potential by allowing passive movement of ions Explanation: Leak channels: Leak channels are a subtype of ion channels that passively allow ions such as Na+/K+ to move across the membrane. They are always open. The most important leak channel is the K+ leak channel, which allows the passive transfer of K+ from inside the cell to outside. This helps in creating the resting membrane potential of the neuron (Option C) The resting membrane potential is crucial for neurons in generating and propagating action potentials. Transmission of action potentials along the axon is facilitated by voltage-gated Na+ channels (Option D) Generation of synaptic potentials at the postsynaptic membrane is facilitated by ligand-gated ion channels. (Option D) Repolarization phase of the action potential is facilitated by voltage gated K+ channel (Option D) Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK26910/#:~:text=K%2B%20leak%20channels%2C%20for%20e xample,ion%20selectivity%20and%20cell%20death. https://med.libretexts.org/Bookshelves/Anatomy_and_Physiolo gy/Anatomy_and_Physiology_(Boundless)/10%3A_Overview_of_the_Nervous_System/10.5%3A_Neurophysiology/1 0.5B%3A_Ion_Channels

questions.question: Which of the following best explains the phenomenon where the distribution of ion species across a semipermeable membrane is influenced by the presence of a non-permeable ion, resulting in an uneven distribution of permeable ions?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Gibbs-Donnan Effect Explanation: Gibbs-Donnan Effect: It is described as the effect of an impermeable ion on the distribution of other ions to which the membrane is permeable (Option C). The non permeable ion influences the distribution of permeable ions in such a way that there will be an unequal distribution of these ions on either side of the membrane. This results in an electrochemical gradient, where the concentration of ions is balanced but not equal due to the presence of non-permeable ions. It helps to create and maintain an uneven distribution of ions between ECF and ICF. Nernst Equation calculates the equilibrium potential for a particular ion across a membrane (Option A) Bohr effect describes how pH and CO 2 concentration affect the oxygen-binding affinity of hemoglobin (Option B) Van’t Hoff law relates to the effect of temperature on the equilibrium constant for a chemical reaction (Option D) Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 8-9, 631 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Van_%27t_Hoff_equation

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT true regarding resting membrane potential?

options.A: It is created by diffusion of K+ from outside to inside the cell at rest
options.B: The RMP of cardiac muscle is -90 mV
options.C: K+ is the major determinant of RMP
options.D: The major contributor of RMP is through passive diffusion of ions

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) It is created by passive diffusion of K+ from outside to inside the cell at rest interior of an excitable cell In any cell, K+ is the major determinant of RMP (option C) The major contribution of RMP is through passive diffusion of K+ ions followed by active diffusion through Na+-K+ ions (option D) Generation of RMP: RMP of different cells: Cell RMP Neuron -70mV Skeletal muscle -95mV Smooth muscle -60mV Cardiac muscle -90mV (option B) Astrocyte -90mV Erythrocyte -12mV Photoreceptor -40mV (dark) to -70mV (light)

questions.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes the type, direction and mediators of axonal transport? 1 Anterograde Cell body to axon terminal Dynein 2 Anterograde Axon terminal to cell body Kinesin 3 Retrograde Axon terminal to cell body Dynein 4 Retrograde Cell body to axon terminal Kinesin
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 3 Explanation: Axonal transport: It is a process in neurons which involves the transport of organelles, proteins and other cellular material along the axon It can be abolished by colchicine, dinitrophenol, azide, cyanide and prolonged anoxia Type Mediated by Characteristics Anterograde transport Kinesin It involves the transport of cellular material from soma to the axon terminal. It is responsible for the transport of proteins, synaptic vesicles necessary for synaptic transmission. Two types: Fast axoplasmic transport at a rate of 400 mm/day, mediated by kinesin. Slow axoplasmic transport at a rate of 0.5-2 mm/day, mediated by actin, neurofilaments and microtubules. Supplies material required for regeneration following nerve injury. Retrograde transport Dynein It involves the transport from axon terminals to soma at a rate of about 200 mm/day. It is important for transport of viruses, toxins, nerve growth factors and reuptake of synaptic neurotransmitters. Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 92-93

questions.question: Which type of neuron is primarily involved in the transmission of visual information from the retina to the brain?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Both multipolar and bipolar neuron Explanation: Transmission of visual information from the retina to the brain is done by the Ganglion cell. Ganglion cell is mostly multipolar but can be bipolar as well Types of neurons: Type Characteristic Unipolar neuron (Option A) Seen in invertebrates Have one process with several receptive and releasing terminals Bipolar neurons (Option B) Seen in retina and olfactory epithelium Have two specialized processes Dendrite carries information to the cell Axon carries information from the cell Pseudo-unipolar neurons Seen in dorsal root ganglion. The developing neuron has a single process that splits into two, both of which function as axons, one reaching up to the skin and the other to the spinal cord Multipolar neurons (Option C) Most common Seen in ganglion cell, hippocampal pyramidal cells, cerebellar Purkinje cells, motor neurons, etc Have one axon and multiple dendrites Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 86 https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/ne uroscience/ganglion-cell#:~:text=Ganglion%20cells%20can%20be%20bipolar,and%20more%20than%20one%20 dendrite).&text=Cell%20size%20varies%20greatly%2C%20with,measuring%2028%20to%2036%20

questions.question: A 30-year-old man presents with progressive muscle weakness and fatigue. Electromyography (EMG) and nerve conduction studies indicate that the issue lies in the transmission of nerve impulses to his muscles, while central nervous system imaging shows no abnormalities. Which part of the neuron is most likely affected?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Axon Terminal Explanation: Axon Terminal triggers the release of neurotransmitters into the synaptic cleft when action potential reaches it, facilitating communication with the next neuron or target cell. Neurons have four important functional zones: 1. Dendritic zone (Receptor zone) Receives information from other neurons and transmits impulses towards the cell body. Integrates local potentials from synaptic connections. 2. Axon Hillock and Initial segment (Action Potential Generation zone) Action potentials are generated here. In motor neurons, it occurs at the axon hillock; in sensory neurons, at the initial node of Ranvier. Summates local potentials from dendrites and generates action potentials if the threshold is reached. 3. Axon (Transmission zone) Long, slender process transmitting action potentials from the cell body to axon terminals. Ensures rapid and efficient propagation of nerve impulses over long distances. 4. Axon Terminal (Discharge zone) Contains synaptic vesicles with neurotransmitters. When an action potential reaches the axon terminal, it triggers neurotransmitter release into the synaptic cleft for communication with other neurons or target cells.

questions.question: In which part of the neuron are neurofibrillary tangles primarily found, which are associated with neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Soma Explanation: Cell body/Soma contain cytoskeletal proteins like neurofilaments, that form characteristic neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer’s. A neuron is the structural and functional unit of the nervous system, identified as an excitable cell due to its ability to generate action potentials when electrically stimulated. The neuron has three parts: Cell body, Dendrite and Axon that ends at the axon terminal. Axon Cell Body (Soma) Dendrites Long tubular process extending from the cell body to transmit signals to target organs. Originates from the axon hillock, a thickened area of the cell body. The initial segment , just after the axon hillock, is where action potentials are generated. Axon terminal: The terminal part of the axon loses myelin and branches into telodendria , which end in synaptic knobs (terminal buttons) containing neurotransmitters. It is the center of the neuron containing the nucleus, which is the metabolic center and stores DNA. Contains organelles like Nissl bodies (stacks of endoplasmic reticulum with ribosomes), mitochondria, Golgi apparatus, and lysosomes. Capable of protein synthesis with numerous Nissl granules. Lacks centrioles, limiting regenerative capacity. Contains cytoskeletal proteins like neurofilaments, microtubules, and actin microfilaments (In Alzheimer’s, neurofilaments form neurofibrillary tangles). These are numerous short extensions from the cell body that receive incoming signals and transmit them into the cell body. Have dendritic spines to increase surface area for signal reception. Contain Nissl granules for protein synthesis; involved in generating and conducting action potentials. Typically, about 10,000 dendrites per neuron are in the CNS. Axons often acquire a myelin sheath, a protein-lipid complex wrapped around the axon. The myelin sheath envelops the axon except at the nodes of Ranvier, periodic 1 micron gaps where the axon is unmyelinated.

questions.question: A 55-year-old patient with brain tumor undergoes treatment with a novel chemotherapy drug targeting tumor cells. Despite the initial response, follow-up imaging shows minimal response and tumor progression. Which characteristic of the blood-brain barrier is responsible for this treatment challenge?

options.C: Presence of fenestrations in capillary walls
options.D: Lack of efflux transporters for drugs

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Impermeability to plasma proteins Explanation: The blood-brain barrier (BBB) is impermeable to plasma proteins and most non-lipid soluble large organic molecules. This limits the effective concentration of therapeutic drugs, such as protein antibodies and non-lipid soluble drugs, in the CSF. Tight junctions between endothelial cells are responsible for the low permeability of the BBB. Blood-Brain Barrier (BBB) The BBB is the barrier between capillary endothelial cells in the brain and epithelial cells in the choroid plexus, limiting the exchange of substances into the brain. Anatomical Basis Formed by two special structures: Endothelial cells in brain capillaries are joined by tight junctions. Capillaries are surrounded by astrocyte foot processes. Permeability Easily Penetrated: Water, CO2, O2, lipid-soluble substances. Not Penetrated: Proteins, polypeptides. Circumventricular organs The BBB is deficient in certain brain regions known as circumventricular organs, which are outside the BBB: Organum vasculosum of lamina terminalis (OVLT) Subfornical Organ Area postrema in medulla oblongata Posterior pituitary and median eminence(ventral part) of hypothalamus Pineal gland Functions of BBB Maintain constancy of Na+, K+, Ca++, H+ and Mg++ in brain fluids Protect neurons from harmful toxins Prevents escape of neurotransmitters from brain into circulation Disruption of BBB helps in identifying the location and extent of lesions in the brain Clinical importance Kernicterus: Hyperbilirubinemia damages the basal ganglia in infants due to an underdeveloped BBB. Brain Tumor : BBB is disrupted at the tumor site. Infection and Injury: BBB breakdown occurs in infected or injured regions. Lipid-soluble substances permeate through BBB easily (Option B) BBB does not have fenestrations. (Option C) Efflux transporter in BBB limits the brain tissue exposure to various potential therapeutic agents. (Option D)
